choices.text: Lactulose acts by acidifying the gut lumen and converting ammonia (NH₃) to non-absorbable ammonium (NH₄⁺)
Rifaximin is a poorly absorbed oral antibiotic that reduces intestinal ammonia production and is preferred in recurrent episodes
Oral neomycin kills urease-positive bacteria in GIT and thus reduces the production of ammonia
Proton pump inhibitors are first-line therapy in hepatic encephalopathy as they reduce gastric acid and ammonia absorption

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis presents with confusion, asterixis, and lethargy. His serum ammonia level is elevated. A diagnosis of hepatic encephalopathy is made, and appropriate treatment is initiated. Which of the following statements regarding the management of hepatic encephalopathy is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Proton pump inhibitors are first-line therapy in hepatic encephalopathy as they reduce gastric acid and ammonia absorption

 

  • No role in ammonia reduction or HE management.
  • PPIs do not reduce ammonia absorption and are not part of standard therapy.
  • Overuse in cirrhosis is associated with increased risk of infections like spontaneous bacterial peritonitis and C. difficile colitis.
  • Not recommended unless specific GI indication (e.g., variceal bleed prophylaxis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lactulose: Correct.

 

  • Mechanism: Non-absorbable disaccharide → fermented in colon → acidifies gut (↓ pH) → converts NH₃ → NH₄⁺ (trapped in lumen, not absorbed).
  • Also acts as cathartic, reducing transit time and promoting ammonia excretion.
  • First-line drug in hepatic encephalopathy.

 

Option B. Rifaximin: Correct.

 

  • Poorly absorbed gut-selective antibiotic.
  • Reduces ammonia-producing gut flora, especially urease-positive bacteria.
  • Used as add-on to lactulose in recurrent HE.
  • Fewer side effects than neomycin.

 

Option C. Neomycin: Correct. 

 

  • Aminoglycoside antibiotic, poorly absorbed orally.
  • Kills urease-positive bacteria (e.g., Klebsiella, Proteus), thereby reducing ammonia production.
  • Less preferred due to ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity, but mechanism is correct.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with atrial fibrillation is being evaluated for long-term anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolism. The cardiologist prefers to start an oral anticoagulant that does not require regular INR monitoring and has a predictable pharmacokinetic profile. Which of the following drugs is administered orally and acts as an anticoagulant?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dabigatran

 

  • Oral anticoagulant, classified as a direct thrombin inhibitor (DTI).
  • Used in:
    • Non-valvular atrial fibrillation (stroke prevention)
    • DVT/PE treatment and prophylaxis
  • Advantages:
    • Fixed dosing, no INR monitoring required
    • Antidote available: Idarucizumab
  • Hence, correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melagatran:

 

  • Also a direct thrombin inhibitor, but not available orally as such.
  • It was developed as an oral prodrug (ximelagatran), which was withdrawn from the market due to hepatotoxicity.
  • Hence, not used clinically today, and not an oral anticoagulant in current use.

 

Option C. Fondaparinux:

 

  • Synthetic pentasaccharide that indirectly inhibits factor Xa via antithrombin III.
  • Given subcutaneously (not oral).
  • Used for DVT, PE, and prophylaxis in high-risk surgeries.
  • Hence, not an oral anticoagulant.

 

Option D. Bivalirudin:

 

  • Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor, mainly used during percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
  • Administered intravenously.
  • Short-acting, hospital use only.
  • Not oral.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with persistent low mood, insomnia, loss of appetite, and reduced interest in daily activities for the past 3 months. She is diagnosed with major depressive disorder and is planned to be started on a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) due to its favorable side effect profile. Which of the following drugs is not a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amitriptyline

 

  • Not an SSRI
  • Belongs to tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs)
  • Inhibits reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine (SNRI action)
  • Also has anticholinergic, antihistaminic, and α1-blocking properties
  • Associated with more side effects, especially in overdose

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Escitalopram:

 

  • A pure SSRI (enantiomer of citalopram)
  • Very commonly prescribed for depression and anxiety
  • Minimal drug interactions, well-tolerated

 

 

Option C. Fluoxetine:

 

  • One of the earliest SSRIs
  • Long half-life
  • Also used in bulimia nervosa and premenstrual dysphoric disorder

 

Option D. Sertraline:

 

  • Another SSRI
  • Commonly used for depression, panic disorder, PTSD, and OCD
  • Safe cardiovascular profile

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with epilepsy is planning her second pregnancy. She is currently taking carbamazepine for seizure control. Her first pregnancy was complicated by the birth of a child with spina bifida. She is now seeking advice to prevent recurrence of neural tube defects in her next pregnancy. What is the recommended dose of folic acid she should start before conception?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4000 µg

 

Neural tube defects (NTDs) are serious birth defects of the brain and spine. The most effective way to prevent NTDs is through adequate intake of folic acid before conception and during early pregnancy. For women who have had a previous pregnancy affected by a neural tube defect, the recommended daily dose of folic acid is higher than the general recommendation.

 

The standard preventive dose of folic acid for women with no history of NTDs is 400 µg (0.4 mg) daily. However, for women who have had a previous pregnancy affected by an NTD, the recommended dose is 4 mg (4000 µg) daily. This higher dose has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of recurrence of neural tube defects.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with altered mental status. His family reports he may have overdosed on an unknown medication. An ECG is done as part of his initial evaluation. Which of the following drug–ECG effect pairs is incorrectly matched in the context of overdose or poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tachycardia – Organophosphates

 

  • Organophosphate poisoning causes muscarinic and nicotinic overstimulation due to acetylcholinesterase inhibition.
  • Classic muscarinic effects: bradycardia, miosis, salivation, lacrimation, urination, diarrhea, bronchorrhea, etc.
  • Bradycardia is much more typical than tachycardia (though nicotinic effects may cause variable HR in some cases).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prolonged PR interval – Lithium: 

 

  • Lithium toxicity can cause bradyarrhythmias including prolonged PR interval, sinus node dysfunction, and even AV block.
  • Due to effects on sodium-potassium channels in cardiac myocytes.

 

Option B. Prolonged QTc interval – Amiodarone:

 

  • Amiodarone can prolong QT interval by blocking potassium channels (class III effect).
  • Interestingly, unlike other QT-prolonging drugs, torsades de pointes is less common with amiodarone.

 

Option C. Wide QRS complex – Amitriptyline

 

  • TCA overdose (e.g., amitriptyline) blocks fast sodium channels, leading to a wide QRS, prolonged QT, and risk of ventricular arrhythmias.
  • Classic finding in TCA toxicity on ECG.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male diabetic presents with recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia. On examination, Pulse: 84 beats/minute, BP: 160/100 mm Hg, Chest and CVS examination unremarkable. Which of the following antihypertensive should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Propranolol

 

Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. In diabetic patients, especially those with recurrent hypoglycemia, beta-blockers can mask the symptoms of hypoglycemia (such as tremors, palpitations, and anxiety) making it difficult for patients to recognize and respond to low blood sugar levels. This can increase the risk of severe hypoglycemia, which can be dangerous. For this reason, non-selective beta-blockers like propranolol are generally avoided in diabetic patients with a history of hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Telmisartan: Telmisartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) and does not interfere with the recognition of hypoglycemia.

 

Option C. Torsemide: Torsemide is a loop diuretic, which does not affect hypoglycemia recognition.

 

Option D. Amlodipine: Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker, and it does not interfere with hypoglycemia symptoms.

 

Therefore, propranolol should be avoided in this patient.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with metastatic lung cancer presents with fatigue, confusion, constipation, and polyuria. Blood tests show a serum calcium level of 15.2 mg/dL (normal: 8.5–10.5 mg/dL). His ECG reveals a shortened QT interval. He is hemodynamically stable but lethargic. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient’s severe hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intravenous infusion of normal saline

 

  • First-line and most immediate treatment in severe hypercalcemia.
  • Hypercalcemia causes polyuria and volume depletion, which reduces renal calcium excretion.
  • IV saline corrects dehydration and increases urinary calcium excretion.
  • Loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide) can be added after rehydration to promote calciuresis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous infusion of pamidronate:

 

  • Pamidronate is a bisphosphonate that inhibits bone resorption by osteoclasts.
  • Effective for long-term control of hypercalcemia (e.g., due to malignancy).
  • Onset of action is slow (24–72 hours), so not suitable as initial therapy.

 

Option B. Oral phosphate supplementation:

 

  • Phosphate binds free calcium and lowers serum levels.
  • However, oral phosphate is poorly tolerated, can cause diarrhea, nephrocalcinosis, and may precipitate calcium-phosphate crystals.
  • Not used in initial management; sometimes used cautiously in refractory cases.

 

Option D. Hemodialysis:

 

  • Reserved for life-threatening or refractory hypercalcemia, especially in patients with renal failure or fluid overload where hydration is contraindicated.
  • Not the initial treatment unless the patient is severely symptomatic and has contraindications to fluid therapy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male from Bihar presents with prolonged fever, weight loss, darkening of the skin, and massive splenomegaly. A bone marrow aspirate reveals intracellular amastigotes consistent with Leishmania donovani. He is diagnosed with visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar). Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spiramycin

 

  • A macrolide antibiotic used in toxoplasmosis, especially during pregnancy.
  • Not effective against Leishmania, and not used in treatment protocols.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium stibogluconate:

 

  • A pentavalent antimonial used for decades to treat visceral leishmaniasis.
  • However, resistance is common in Bihar, India, so it is now less preferred there.
  • Still effective in some other regions.

 

Option B. Amphotericin B:

 

  • Liposomal amphotericin B is currently the drug of choice in India (especially Bihar), due to high efficacy and reduced resistance.
  • Directly targets ergosterol in parasite membrane, causing lysis.

 

Option D. Miltefosine:

 

  • The first oral drug for leishmaniasis.
  • Used widely in India; contraindicated in pregnancy due to teratogenicity.
  • Resistance is emerging, so not used as monotherapy in some cases.

questions.text: A patient developed difficulty in standing from a seated position, walking up steps, squatting, and lifting arms overhead. Chronic therapy with which of the following drugs is likely to result in such presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glucocorticoids

 

The symptoms described suggest proximal muscle weakness, which is a common side effect of long-term glucocorticoid therapy. Chronic use of glucocorticoids can lead to steroid myopathy, which typically affects the proximal muscles, leading to difficulty in tasks such as standing up from a seated position, climbing stairs, squatting, and lifting the arms overhead.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetaminophen: Acetaminophen is a pain reliever and fever reducer and does not cause muscle weakness.

 

Option B. Fexofenadine: Fexofenadine is an antihistamine used for allergic symptoms and does not cause muscle weakness.

 

Option D. Metformin: Metformin is an oral hypoglycemic agent used for type 2 diabetes and is not associated with muscle weakness.

 

Therefore, the most likely drug causing the presentation of muscle weakness described is glucocorticoids. Thus, the correct answer is (c) Glucocorticoids.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with breast cancer and lung metastases is undergoing combination chemotherapy, including an alkylating agent. After 2 cycles, she presents with painless hematuria, urinary frequency, and suprapubic discomfort. Urinalysis shows numerous red blood cells but no signs of infection. Cystoscopy reveals diffuse hemorrhagic inflammation of the bladder mucosa. Which of the following is used to treat this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prednisolone

 

  • Prednisolone is a glucocorticoid used to suppress bladder inflammation in established hemorrhagic cystitis.
  • May reduce bleeding and inflammation when bladder mucosa is already damaged.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mesna:

 

  • Mesna is a uroprotective agent that binds acrolein, a toxic metabolite of cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide.
  • Used for prevention of hemorrhagic cystitis, not for treatment once it has occurred.

 

Option C. Amifostine:

 

  • Cytoprotective agent used primarily to prevent cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity and radiation-induced xerostomia.
  • Not indicated for cyclophosphamide-induced bladder toxicity.

 

Option D. Pirfenidone:

 

  • An anti-fibrotic drug used in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.
  • No role in the treatment or prevention of hemorrhagic cystitis

choices.text: It is a rare complication and occurs 2-3 weeks after acute exposure.
It is a feature of poisoning with certain organophosphorus compounds such as triorthocresyl phosphate.
Inhibition of acetylcholinesterase causes motor polyneuropathy with no evidence of sensory loss.
There is no specific therapy although regular physiotherapy may limit deformity caused by muscle wasting.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding organophosphate-induced delayed polyneuropathy (OPIDN) is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibition of acetylcholinesterase causes motor polyneuropathy with no evidence of sensory loss.

 

ORGANOPHOSPHATE-INDUCED DELAYED POLYNEUROPATHY (OPIDP) 

 

  • Introduction: It is a rare toxicity resulting from exposure to certain organophosphorus (OP) esters like tri-ortho-cresyl phosphate 
  • Pathogenesis: It is characterised by distal degeneration of some axons of both the peripheral and central nervous systems occurring 2-3 weeks after single or short-term exposures. Nerve biopsies shows axonal degeneration with secondary demyelination. Neuropathy target esterase (NTE) is thought to be the target of OPIDP initiation.. 
  • Symptoms: It can present as motor as well sensory neuropathy. Cramping muscle pain in the lower limbs, distal numbness and paraesthesiae occur, followed by progressive weakness, depression of deep tendon reflexes in the lower limbs and, in severe cases, in the upper limbs. Signs include high-stepping gait associated with bilateral foot drop and, in severe cases, quadriplegia with foot and wrist drop as well as pyramidal signs.
  • Recovery: In time, there might be significant recovery of the peripheral nerve function but, depending on the degree of pyramidal involvement, spastic ataxia may be a permanent outcome of severe OPIDP. Recovery is usually complete in the young. 

 

While acetylcholinesterase inhibition is a mechanism of acute organophosphate toxicity, OPIDN is believed to involve a different mechanism related to neuropathy target esterase (NTE) inhibition. Moreover, OPIDN can present with both motor and sensory symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a rare complication and occurs 2-3 weeks after acute exposure: This statement is correct. Organophosphate-induced delayed polyneuropathy (OPIDN) is a rare condition that typically occurs 2-3 weeks after acute exposure to certain organophosphates.

 

Option B. It is a feature of poisoning with certain organophosphorus compounds such as triorthocresyl phosphate: This statement is correct. OPIDN is associated with exposure to certain organophosphorus compounds, including triorthocresyl phosphate.

 

Option D. There is no specific therapy although regular physiotherapy may limit deformity caused by muscle wasting: This statement is correct. There is no specific treatment for OPIDN, and management primarily involves supportive care, including physiotherapy to prevent deformities and manage muscle wasting.

choices.text: Toxicity is caused by an intermediate reactive metabolite that binds covalently to cellular proteins causing cell death.
Antidotes for paracetamol act by replenishing hepatic glutathione and should be administered to all patients with acute poisoning.
Intravenous acetylcysteine is a highly efficacious antidote if administered within 8 hours of the overdose.
Methionine may be used as an alternative antidote but it is less effective than acetylcysteine.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents to the emergency department 6 hours after ingesting an unknown quantity of paracetamol (acetaminophen) tablets in a suicide attempt. She is alert but anxious. Vital signs are stable, and her physical exam is unremarkable. The treating physician orders liver function tests and starts treatment with N-acetylcysteine. Consider the following statements regarding paracetamol toxicity. Which one is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antidotes for paracetamol act by replenishing hepatic glutathione and should be administered to all patients with acute poisoning.

 

  • Partially true – yes, the antidotes replenish glutathione or act as glutathione substitutes.
  • BUT: They are not given to all patients.
    • Risk assessment is done using the Rumack-Matthew nomogram, based on serum paracetamol levels and time of ingestion.
    • If below the treatment line, NAC may not be indicated.
    • Thus, NAC is not automatically given to every paracetamol overdose – only when risk of hepatotoxicity is significant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxicity is caused by an intermediate reactive metabolite that binds covalently to cellular proteins causing cell death: Correct.

 

  • Paracetamol is primarily metabolized via conjugation (glucuronidation and sulfation). A small fraction is metabolized via CYP450 to a toxic metabolite called NAPQI (N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine).
  • When glutathione stores are depleted, NAPQI binds to hepatocellular proteins → oxidative damage → centrilobular hepatic necrosis.

 

Option C. Intravenous acetylcysteine is a highly efficacious antidote if administered within 8 hours of the overdose: Correct.

 

  • IV N-acetylcysteine is most effective if started within 8 hours.
  • It prevents hepatic injury by replenishing glutathione, enhancing sulfate conjugation, and directly detoxifying NAPQI.

 

Option D. Methionine may be used as an alternative antidote but it is less effective than acetylcysteine: Correct.

 

  • Oral methionine acts as a glutathione precursor and is effective only if given within 10 hours of overdose.
  • It is less effective than NAC and is typically used when NAC is unavailable, especially in resource-limited settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • NAPQI is the toxic metabolite in paracetamol overdose.
  • Treatment decisions are not universal, but based on timing and paracetamol level.
  • NAC is the antidote of choice and most effective within 8 hours.
  • Methionine is a backup, oral option.

questions.text: All of the following agents are used in the management of acute hyperkalemia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nebulized ipratropium bromide

 

Nebulized ipratropium bromide is used for bronchodilation in conditions like asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is not used in the management of hyperkalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10% calcium gluconate intravenously: This is correct. Intravenous calcium gluconate is used to stabilize the cardiac membranes in hyperkalemia, reducing the risk of life-threatening arrhythmias.

 

Option B. Regular insulin and intravenous glucose: This is correct. Insulin, administered with glucose to prevent hypoglycemia, helps to shift potassium into cells, lowering serum potassium levels.

 

Option D. Intravenous sodium bicarbonate: This is correct. Intravenous sodium bicarbonate can be used to treat hyperkalemia, especially if acidosis is present. It helps to shift potassium into cells and corrects acidosis.

 

In conclusion, the treatments used in the management of hyperkalemia are 10% calcium gluconate intravenously, regular insulin and intravenous glucose, and intravenous sodium bicarbonate. Therefore, the correct answer is (b) 1, 2, and 4.

choices.text: It acts as a selective progesterone receptor modulator that delays ovulation even after the LH surge has begun.
It is effective as emergency contraception when taken as a single 30 mg dose within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.
It is contraindicated in women with moderate to severe hepatic impairment.
It is safely co-administered with levonorgestrel to enhance contraceptive efficacy.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic seeking emergency contraception after unprotected intercourse approximately 48 hours ago. She is otherwise healthy with regular menstrual cycles and a negative urine pregnancy test. The clinician decides to prescribe ulipristal acetate. All of the following statements regarding ulipristal acetate are correct except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is safely co-administered with levonorgestrel to enhance contraceptive efficacy.

 

  • Ulipristal should not be co-administered with levonorgestrel or other hormonal contraceptives.
  • Doing so may reduce the efficacy of both, as they have opposing actions on progesterone receptors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It acts as a selective progesterone receptor modulator that delays ovulation even after the LH surge has begun:

 

  • Ulipristal acetate is a selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM).
  • It inhibits or delays ovulation even after the LH surge, unlike levonorgestrel.

 

Option B. It is effective as emergency contraception when taken as a single 30 mg dose within 5 days of unprotected intercourse:

 

  • The recommended dose for emergency contraception is 30 mg orally, single dose, and it is effective up to 120 hours (5 days) after unprotected intercourse.

 

Option C. It is contraindicated in women with moderate to severe hepatic impairment:

 

  • Moderate to severe hepatic impairment is a contraindication due to the hepatic metabolism of ulipristal and potential accumulation/toxicity.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic for evaluation of irregular spotting between periods. She has been on combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) for the past 6 months for contraception. She denies any significant weight gain, nausea, or breast tenderness. However, she complains of mild skin pigmentation on the cheeks and occasional headaches. Which of the following is considered a major complication associated with the use of oral contraceptive pills?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cholestasis jaundice

 

Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) contain estrogen and progestin, and they are associated with a variety of minor side effects, major complications, and some beneficial effects.

 

  • Mechanism: Estrogens impair bile flow by reducing bile acid secretion, leading to intrahepatic cholestasis.
  • This can manifest as jaundice, pruritus, and elevated liver enzymes.
  • Though not very common, it is a serious complication and requires discontinuation of OCPs.
  • Especially important in patients with underlying liver disease or genetic predisposition (e.g. Dubin-Johnson syndrome).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloasma and acne:

 

  • Chloasma (melasma) is estrogen-induced pigmentation, usually on the face.
  • Acne can sometimes worsen with progestins, though some OCPs (e.g. those with drospirenone) actually improveacne.
  • These are cosmetic issues and are not considered major complications.

 

Option C. Breakthrough bleeding 

 

  • It is very common, especially in the first few months of COCP use.
  • Usually self-limiting, and often due to inadequate estrogen levels.
  • Easily managed by changing the formulation or reassuring the patient.
  • Hence, not a major concern.

 

Option D. Exacerbation of migraine: Important but not considered "major" complication in general use

 

  • COCPs can worsen migraines, particularly in women with migraine with aura, due to increased risk of ischemic stroke.
  • In such cases, COCPs are contraindicated.
  • However, migraine exacerbation alone is not a universal major complication in all OCP users, unlike cholestasis which can affect liver function directly.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man undergoing chemotherapy for acute leukemia presents with fever and severe neutropenia. Blood cultures are sent, and empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated. In such high-risk immunocompromised patients, the choice of antibiotic should aim for rapid bacterial clearance. Which of the following antibiotics would be least appropriate as part of the initial therapy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Linezolid

 

In a patient with febrile neutropenia, particularly one undergoing chemotherapy for leukemia, the immune system is severely compromised, especially due to the lack of neutrophils. These patients are at high risk for rapid progression of infection and sepsis. In such scenarios, it is essential to use bactericidal antibiotics—those that directly kill bacteria—rather than bacteriostatic drugs, which only inhibit bacterial growth and rely on the host immune system to clear the infection.

 

Option A. Gentamicin: It is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that binds irreversibly to the 30S ribosomal subunit, causing misreading of mRNA and production of non-functional proteins, leading to bacterial cell death. It is bactericidal and effective against gram-negative bacteria, including Pseudomonas, making it highly suitable for febrile neutropenia. 

 

Option B. Vancomycin: It is a glycopeptide that inhibits peptidoglycan synthesis in the bacterial cell wall and is bactericidal against gram-positive organisms. It is commonly used in neutropenic patients when there is concern for MRSA or catheter-related bloodstream infections. 

 

Option C. Levofloxacin: Levofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone, inhibits bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, and is also bactericidal. It is frequently used both for prophylaxis and treatment of febrile neutropenia due to its broad-spectrum activity, especially against gram-negative organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In contrast, Linezolid is an oxazolidinone that binds to the 50S ribosomal subunit and prevents the formation of the initiation complex in bacterial protein synthesis. It is primarily bacteriostatic (except against some streptococci), meaning it halts bacterial replication but does not actively kill the organisms. While it has excellent activity against resistant gram-positive organisms like MRSA and VRE, its bacteriostatic nature makes it a less suitable option for febrile neutropenia, where rapid bacterial clearance is essential. Therefore, among the given options, Linezolid is least appropriate as initial empirical therapy in this setting.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male agricultural worker from a rural area presents with fever, eschar at the site of an insect bite, and generalized lymphadenopathy. He also complains of myalgia and mild cough. Laboratory testing shows elevated liver enzymes. A diagnosis of scrub typhus is made. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oral doxycycline

 

Scrub typhus, caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, is transmitted by chigger bites and is endemic in many parts of Asia, including India. The drug of choice is oral doxycycline, which is highly effective and well-absorbed even in moderately ill patients. Most cases respond within 48–72 hours of initiation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV doxycycline: IV doxycycline is typically reserved for patients who cannot tolerate oral medication or have severe illness with vomiting, hypotension, or organ dysfunction. However, oral doxycycline remains first-line in uncomplicated cases due to its excellent oral bioavailability.

 

Option B. IV doxycycline + oral azithromycin and Option D. Oral doxycycline + oral azithromycin) are not standard regimens. Combination therapy may be considered in severe, refractory, or complicated scrub typhus, or in pregnant patients when doxycycline use is controversial, but they are not the first-line in uncomplicated disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oral doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 5–7 days is the drug of choice for scrub typhus.
  • In pregnancy or doxycycline resistance, azithromycin is an effective alternative.

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravida at 24 weeks of gestation presents with elevated blood pressure readings on two occasions (150/96 mmHg and 148/94 mmHg). She has a history of bronchial asthma since childhood, for which she uses an as-needed salbutamol inhaler. She is otherwise healthy, with no proteinuria or other systemic signs. The obstetrician plans to start an antihypertensive. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line antihypertensive in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alpha methyldopa

 

Alpha methyldopa is a centrally acting antihypertensive that is considered safe in pregnancy and has long been used as a first-line agent for gestational hypertension. It has no adverse effect on airway reactivity, making it suitable for patients with bronchial asthma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lisinopril: An ACE inhibitor is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its risk of fetal renal dysgenesis, oligohydramnios, skull ossification defects, and even fetal death, especially during the second and third trimesters. It should never be used in pregnant women.

 

Option C. Amlodipine: A calcium channel blocker, is not contraindicated in pregnancy and is sometimes used, but it is not the first-line agent. It is generally reserved as a second-line option.

 

Option D. Labetalol: A combined alpha and beta blocker, is commonly used as a first-line antihypertensive in pregnancy. However, its beta-blocking component can precipitate bronchospasm in asthmatic patients, especially those with moderate-to-severe disease or recent exacerbations. Therefore, it is not preferred in asthmatics, despite being generally safe in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In pregnancy with asthma, prefer alpha methyldopa or calcium channel blockers (e.g. nifedipine).
  • Avoid beta blockers (like labetalol) in asthmatics and never use ACE inhibitors like lisinopril in pregnancy.

questions.text: A weakly acidic drug has a pKa of 4.0. For maximum absorption, the drug needs to be in its non-ionized (lipid-soluble) form to cross cell membranes. At which of the following sites will this drug exist predominantly in its lipid-soluble, non-ionized form?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stomach (pH 2.0)

 

The degree of ionization of a drug depends on the pH of the environment and the pKa of the drug, as described by the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation. For a weak acid, the non-ionized (lipid-soluble) form predominates in acidic environments, where pH < pKa.

 

At (pH 2.0) stomach: Since pH < pKa (4.0), the drug remains mostly non-ionized, making it lipid-soluble and well absorbed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duodenum (pH 6.0): pH > pKa → more of the drug is ionized (less lipid-soluble).

 

Option D. Blood (pH 7.4) and Option C. Jejunum (pH 8.0): Farther above pKa → drug is mostly ionized, hence poorly lipid-soluble.

 

This explains why weakly acidic drugs like aspirin are better absorbed in the acidic stomach than in the alkaline intestine.

questions.text: A 66-year-old postmenopausal woman is being evaluated for osteoporosis. Her DEXA scan reveals a T-score of -2.8. She has no history of fractures or malignancy. The endocrinologist is considering pharmacological therapy that improves bone mass. Which of the following drugs used in osteoporosis management does not act primarily by inhibiting osteoclasts?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Teriparatide

 

  • Teriparatide is a recombinant parathyroid hormone (PTH 1–34) analog. Unlike the other options, it works by stimulating osteoblast activity, thereby increasing bone formation. It is the only anabolic agent among common osteoporosis drugs. Although PTH in continuous exposure increases bone resorption, intermittent low doses (as in teriparatide) actually favor bone formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strontium ranelate: Strontium ranelate has a dual mechanism. it decreases bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclasts and increases bone formation by stimulating osteoblasts. So it still acts partly via osteoclast inhibition.

 

Option B. Ibandronate: Ibandronate is a bisphosphonate that strongly inhibits osteoclast-mediated bone resorption by inducing osteoclast apoptosis.

 

Option D. Calcitonin: Calcitonin is a hormone that directly inhibits osteoclastic bone resorption and is used especially for acute relief in vertebral fracture pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In osteoporosis, most drugs are anti-resorptive (like bisphosphonates, SERMs, calcitonin), while teriparatide and abaloparatide are bone-forming (anabolic) agents.

questions.text: A 70-year-old diabetic male with recurrent urinary tract infections is found to have E. coli in urine culture. Sensitivity testing reveals the organism produces extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs). Which of the following antibiotics is most appropriate for treating this infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meropenem

 

Extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs) are enzymes produced by certain Gram-negative bacteria (especially E. coliand Klebsiella) that hydrolyze and inactivate penicillins, cephalosporins (including 3rd-generation like ceftriaxone), and aztreonam.

 

Meropenem is a carbapenem, which is resistant to ESBLs and is the drug of choice for serious infections caused by ESBL-producing organisms. It remains active because carbapenems are structurally resistant to most beta-lactamases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoxicillin: Amoxicillin is a penicillin and is completely ineffective against ESBL-producing organisms, as it is easily broken down by beta-lactamases.

 

Option C. Piperacillin: Piperacillin although broader-spectrum, is still a penicillin derivative and is not effective against ESBLs unless combined with a beta-lactamase inhibitor (e.g., tazobactam), and even then, resistance can occur.

 

Option D. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, which is inactivated by ESBLs, and thus not reliable for treatment.

choices.text: It is first-line drug in patients with prior history of stroke
It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel
Omeprazole interferes with metabolism of prasugrel leading to increased risk of bleeding

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with recent coronary stenting is prescribed dual antiplatelet therapy including aspirin and prasugrel. Which of the following statements regarding prasugrel is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a pro-drug

 

Prasugrel is a pro-drug, meaning it requires metabolic activation to convert into its active form. However, unlike clopidogrel, which is highly dependent on CYP2C19, prasugrel is activated via CYP3A4 and CYP2B6, making its effect more consistent and less affected by genetic polymorphisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is first-line drug in patients with prior history of stroke: Incorrect. Prasugrel is contraindicated in patients with a history of stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA). Its use in such individuals has been associated with a significantly increased risk of intracranial hemorrhage. Therefore, it is not only not first-line, but actually should be avoided in this group.

 

Option B. It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel: Incorrect. Prasugrel is more potent than clopidogrel, not less. It produces more consistent and greater inhibition of platelet aggregation. However, this increased potency also translates to a higher risk of bleeding, particularly in vulnerable populations.

 

Option D. Omeprazole interferes with metabolism of prasugrel leading to increased risk of bleeding: Incorrect. Omeprazole is known to inhibit CYP2C19, which interferes with the activation of clopidogrel but not prasugrel. Prasugrel’s activation relies mainly on CYP3A4 and CYP2B6, not CYP2C19. Thus, PPIs like omeprazole do not significantly affect the efficacy or safety of prasugrel.

questions.text: A 2-month pregnant female presented with Plasmodium vivax malaria. Which of the following is the appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Quinine

 

For a pregnant woman with Plasmodium vivax malaria, Chloroquine alone is the appropriate choice. Primaquine is contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential risks to the fetus. Quinine is normally used for Plasmodium falciparum malaria but can be used in P. vivax malaria also if other options are not available. It is safe in pregnancy. ACTs are generally avoided in the first trimester, and Doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy. Therefore, Chloroquine, without Primaquine, is the safest and most effective option in this case. However, as it is not in the options, so the next best option i.e. quinine will be the answer.

 

Quinine is often used as a treatment for malaria during pregnancy, especially if other options are not available or suitable. However, it is usually more associated with the treatment of Plasmodium falciparum rather than Plasmodium vivax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chloroquine plus Primaquine: Chloroquine is considered safe and effective for the treatment of Plasmodium vivax malaria during pregnancy. However, primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of hemolytic anemia in the fetus, especially if there is G6PD deficiency, which cannot be tested for in the fetus.

 

Option C. Artemisinin-Based Combination Therapy (ACT): While ACTs are very effective in treating Plasmodium falciparum malaria, their safety profile in the first trimester of pregnancy is not well-established. Generally, they are avoided in the first trimester unless no other options are available.

 

Option D. Doxycycline: Doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of interfering with bone and teeth development in the fetus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is scheduled for a minor surgical procedure under local anesthesia. She reports a previous severe allergic reaction including urticaria and wheezing following a dental procedure where tetracaine was used. Which of the following local anesthetics would be safest to administer in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lignocaine

 

Tetracaine is an ester-type local anesthetic, and allergy to one ester LA usually implies a risk of cross-reactivity with other ester LAs (e.g., procaine, chloroprocaine, benzocaine). This is because esters are metabolized to para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA), a known allergen.

 

Amide-type LAs (like lignocaine, bupivacaine, ropivacaine) are structurally different, and cross-reactivity is extremely rare between ester and amide groups. Therefore, lignocaine is safe and preferred in patients with a known allergy to an ester-type anesthetic.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents for routine follow-up. His HbA1c is 7.9%. He is overweight and has a history of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). The physician decides to initiate a new medication that improves glycemic control, promotes weight loss, and provides cardiovascular and renal protection. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate drug the physician is deciding to start?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Empagliflozin

 

  • Empagliflozin is a SGLT-2 inhibitor that acts by blocking sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 in the proximal renal tubules, leading to increased urinary glucose excretion (glucosuria). This mechanism is insulin-independent, and helps in reducing HbA1c, body weight, and blood pressure.
  • It also has strong evidence supporting use in cardiovascular disease and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), independent of glucose levels. Additionally, SGLT-2 inhibitors slow progression of diabetic nephropathy, though their efficacy may diminish as eGFR falls below 30.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acarbose: Acarbose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that delays carbohydrate absorption from the intestine — it does not cause glucosuria.

 

Option B. Glipizide: Glipizide is a sulfonylurea that increases insulin secretion from pancreatic β-cells — again, no glucosuria.

 

Option D. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor that inhibits degradation of incretin hormones (GLP-1, GIP), enhancing insulin secretion and reducing glucagon levels — no effect on renal glucose reabsorption.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought for psychiatric evaluation by her family. When the psychiatrist asks, "How old are you?", she responds: "Age is just a number, and while age is important, the wisdom is sometimes more important. Wisdom can come from age and also from education, ah, education is so important, I wish I could go for higher education." This pattern of speech is best described as:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Tangentiality

questions.text: Obsessions are disorders of:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Possession of Thought

Start Venlafaxine at the dose of 75 mg per day and increase to 150 mg in a week

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with depression and started on fluoxetine 20 mg, presents one week later with decreased need for sleep, overtalkativeness, grandiose ideas claiming he is "the chosen one," increased goal-directed activity, and inappropriate sexual advances to nursing staff. He speaks rapidly, jumping from topic to topic. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Stop fluoxetine and start risperidone

questions.text: A 45-year-old college professor is referred for psychiatric evaluation by his department head. He works 14 hours daily, refuses to take vacations claiming "the work won't be done properly without me," and is constantly critical of the university's administrative systems. He insists all assignments must be graded in a specific color-coded system and becomes extremely upset when colleagues don't follow his methods. His wife complains he spends more time organizing his office than with family. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder

questions.solution: Ans. B) Female sex

questions.text: A patient had 3 episodes of moderate depression and one episode of hypomania in the last 2 years. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Bipolar II disorder

choices.text: For acute mania, therapeutic lithium levels should be maintained between 0.8-1.0 mEq/L
For maintenance treatment, lithium levels should be between 0.4-0.8 mEq/L

questions.text: A 28-year-old man diagnosed with bipolar disorder has been on lithium therapy for the past 6 months. He presents for routine monitoring. His psychiatrist advises him about therapeutic drug monitoring. Which of the following statements about lithium levels is incorrect?
questions.solution: Ans. A) For acute mania, therapeutic lithium levels should be maintained between 0.8-1.0 mEq/L

questions.text: A middle-aged female presented with complaints of repeated episodes of around 30 minutes characterised by breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation, and a fear of impending heart attack. The patient has had these episodes 5-6 times/month in the last 6 months, and the investigations didn't reveal any obvious abnormality. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Cognitive Behavioural Therapy

questions.text: Which neural circuit dysfunction is primarily implicated in the pathophysiology of obsessive-compulsive disorder?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical (CSTC) circuit

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with 6-month history of recurrent abdominal bloating and discomfort. She has consulted multiple specialists and undergone extensive investigations including endoscopy, CT scan, and blood tests - all results are normal. Despite reassurances, she remains extremely distressed about her symptoms and spends hours daily researching possible causes online. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Somatic symptom disorder

questions.text: A 21-year-old female presents with sudden onset paralysis of her left leg following a breakup with her boyfriend. Neurological examination and all investigations including MRI are normal. During the consultation, she appears remarkably unconcerned about her paralysis and instead focuses on discussing her relationship problems. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Conversion disorder

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the OPD complaining that while listening to music, he sees geometric shapes like triangles floating in the air, which frightens him. He reports these episodes started after attending a party last weekend. Which substance has he most likely used?
questions.solution: Ans. A) LSD

questions.text: A 24-year-old medical intern was brought to the emergency department after a party where he consumed excessive alcohol. His friends report that during the party, he appeared coherent and shared a detailed plan to get rank 1 in the INICET exam, but the next morning, he had no recollection of the same and was saying that he would start preparing in the drop year. At what blood alcohol concentration does this phenomenon typically occur?
questions.solution: Ans. C) 200-300 mg/dL

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents due to significant weight loss, extreme dietary restriction, and excessive exercising for the past 8 months. She has a BMI of 15 kg/m² and has had amenorrhea for 6 months. A diagnosis of anorexia nervosa is made. Which hormonal profile is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B) ↓ GnRH, ↓ FSH, ↑ Cortisol

Modafinil is the drug of choice
Characterised by decreased latency of NREM sleep
