questions.solution: Ans. D) Characterised by decreased latency of NREM sleep

choices.text: Methohexital is the anesthetic agent of choice
Anterograde amnesia is the most common side effect of ECT
Prolonged seizure occurs if seizure continues for more than 180 seconds
Raised intracranial tension is considered a relative contraindication

questions.text: All of the following statements about Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT) are correct except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Anterograde amnesia is the most common side effect of ECT

questions.text: A new FDA approved drug for Rett's syndrome is?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Trofinetide

choices.text: Plain CT scan of paranasal sinuses

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with nasal congestion, frequent episodes of spontaneous epistaxis, and a gradually enlarging facial swelling. On anterior rhinoscopy, a reddish, fleshy mass is seen occupying the nasal cavity. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation to evaluate the extent and vascularity of the suspected lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Contrast-enhanced CT scan

 

This is the investigation of choice for suspected JNA. It shows the classic features like the Holman-Miller sign (anterior bowing of the posterior maxillary sinus wall), and helps assess extent into the pterygopalatine fossa, orbit, infratemporal fossa, and even early intracranial spread.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plain CT scan of paranasal sinuses: While useful for assessing bony erosion, it lacks the ability to evaluate vascularity or enhancement patterns which are crucial in juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA).

 

Option B. MRI brain with contrast: MRI is more sensitive for soft tissue and intracranial extension, but for initial assessment of bony erosion and staging, CECT remains superior and more accessible.

 

Option D. Diagnostic biopsy under general anesthesia: Dangerous and contraindicated. Due to the high vascularity and absence of contractile components in vessels, biopsy may cause life-threatening bleeding. Diagnosis is clinical + radiological.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In adolescent males with epistaxis and nasal mass suggestive of JNA, contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice to evaluate extent and vascularity, while biopsy must be strictly avoided.

choices.text: Injury to external branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman undergoes total thyroidectomy for a multinodular goiter. Post-operatively, she develops inspiratory stridor and is unable to be weaned off the endotracheal tube. What is the most likely cause for this airway compromise?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

 

Both vocal cords lie in the paramedian position, unable to abduct, causing severe airway obstruction. Due to unopposed action of cricothyroid (via SLN), the cords are pulled medially (Wagner & Grossman theory). This leads to stridor and respiratory distress, often necessitating emergency tracheostomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypocalcemic tetany: While hypocalcemia is a known complication of thyroidectomy, it presents with perioral numbness, muscle cramps, Chvostek’s or Trousseau’s sign — not stridor requiring airway support immediately post-op.

 

Option B. Injury to external branch of superior laryngeal nerve: This causes voice pitch change due to cricothyroid paralysis but does not lead to airway obstruction or stridor.

 

Option D. Seroma formation: While it can cause neck swelling and some pressure, it’s not the most likely cause of stridor and inability to extubate immediately after surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy after thyroidectomy causes paramedian vocal cord positioning with airway obstruction and stridor, often requiring emergency tracheostomy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss in the right ear. Otoscopic examination reveals a reddish, pulsatile mass behind an intact tympanic membrane. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glomus tympanicum

 

It is the most common benign middle ear tumor, arising from the promontory. It presents as a pulsatile reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane and causes pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss. Brown’s sign may be positive (blanching with pressure via Siegel’s speculum), and biopsy is contraindicated due to vascularity.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High-riding jugular bulb: While it can appear as a bluish mass through the tympanic membrane, it typically does not present with pulsatile red mass or cause significant conductive hearing loss. It’s also less likely to be symptomatic unless dehiscent.

 

 

Option C. Barotrauma-induced hemorrhage: This may show blood behind the TM (hemotympanum), but pulsation or vascular blush is absent. Also, there's usually a history of trauma or pressure change.

 

 

Option D. Congenital cholesteatoma: Appears as a pearly white mass, not red, and is not vascular. It does not pulsate and is typically asymptomatic unless secondarily infected or large.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A pulsatile red mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in a patient with tinnitus and conductive hearing loss is characteristic of glomus tympanicum.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with nasal obstruction, persistent crusting, and foul-smelling discharge. Despite this, she is unaware of the odor. On examination, the nasal cavities are roomy with pale mucosa and multiple adherent crusts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atrophic rhinitis

 

This condition features atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinates, leading to a roomy nasal cavity, pale mucosa, foul-smelling crusts, and anosmia (due to atrophy of olfactory nerve endings). Because the patient cannot perceive the bad odor, it is referred to as "merciful anosmia." Crusting occurs due to loss of cilia and mucous glands. Primary causes include hereditary, endocrine, and nutritional factors (mnemonic: HERNIA).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinoscleroma: A chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It presents with nasal obstruction and crusting, but is characterized by woody induration, nodules, and scarring, not merciful anosmia or pale atrophic mucosa.

 

 

Option C. Acute bacterial rhinosinusitis: Usually presents with purulent nasal discharge, facial pain, and fever. It does not involve pale, roomy nasal cavities or merciful anosmia.

 

Option D. Deviated nasal septum: Can cause nasal obstruction, but not associated with crusting, foul smell, or mucosal atrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic rhinitis presents with nasal crusting, foul smell, roomy cavities, and merciful anosmia, due to mucosal and neural atrophy.

choices.text: Chronic suppurative otitis media – tubotympanic type

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought with complaints of painless ear discharge and hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals multiple small perforations in the tympanic membrane and pale granulation tissue in the middle ear. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tuberculous otitis media

 

Classic features include:

 

  • Multiple perforations in the tympanic membrane.
  • Pale granulation tissue in the middle ear.
  • Painless otorrhea with disproportionate hearing loss.
  • History of contact with TB or pulmonary TB.
  • Facial palsy may also be seen in some cases.
  • Caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis reaching the middle ear via Eustachian tube or hematogenous route.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otomycosis: Fungal infection of the external auditory canal. Presents with itching, black or white fungal debris, but not multiple perforations or pale granulations. Tympanic membrane is typically intact or only mildly inflamed.

 

 

Option B. Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), tubotympanic type: Presents with a single central perforation and mucopurulent discharge. It may have granulations, but not pale, nor are multiple perforations characteristic.

 

 

Option D. Acute otitis media (AOM): Usually presents with pain, fever, and bulging TM. Perforation may occur, but it's single and recent, not multiple or chronic. Granulation tissue is not a feature.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculous otitis media should be suspected in a child with multiple tympanic membrane perforations, pale granulations, and painless persistent otorrhea.

choices.text: Perform needle aspiration of the abscess

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with high-grade fever, sore throat, drooling of saliva, and difficulty opening the mouth. On oral examination, the tonsil is bulging medially, with uvular deviation to the opposite side. What is the most appropriate immediate management step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perform needle aspiration of the abscess

 

This is both diagnostic and therapeutic. Needle aspiration confirms the presence of pus and relieves the pressure. It is the first step in management of a peritonsillar abscess, along with initiation of IV antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start oral amoxicillin-clavulanate: Oral antibiotics are insufficient in the presence of a frank abscess, especially when the child has trismus and is unable to swallow. This is not the first-line approach in this case.

 

Option B. Administer intravenous dexamethasone: Steroids can reduce inflammation and trismus, but they are adjunctive therapy and do not address the source of infection (i.e., pus). Drainage is required first.

 

Option D. Schedule immediate tonsillectomy: Referred to as "hot tonsillectomy," this is usually avoided due to bleeding risk. Interval tonsillectomy (after ~6 weeks) may be considered in recurrent cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Needle aspiration is the first step in managing peritonsillar abscess, as it confirms diagnosis and provides immediate decompression of pus.

choices.text: Rinne negative in left ear, Rinne positive in right ear, Weber lateralized to left ear
Rinne positive in both ears, Weber lateralized to right ear
Rinne negative in both ears, Weber does not lateralize
Rinne positive in left ear, Rinne negative in right ear, Weber lateralized to left ear

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with complaints of decreased hearing in the left ear. An audiogram is performed and is shown below. Which of the following tuning fork test findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rinne negative in left ear, Rinne positive in right ear, Weber lateralized to left ear

 

The audiogram shows left-sided (blue colour) conductive hearing loss:

 

  • Air conduction (X) is worse than bone conduction (<) on the left.
  • Right ear appears normal.

 

In conductive hearing loss:

 

  • Rinne test is negative on the affected side (BC > AC).
  • Weber test lateralizes to the affected ear (due to increased bone perception).
  • The opposite (normal) side shows Rinne positive (AC > BC).

 

So:

 

  • Left ear → Rinne negative
  • Right ear → Rinne positive
  • Weber lateralizes to the left (affected ear)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rinne positive in both ears, Weber lateralized to right ear: Suggests sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear (Rinne remains positive, Weber goes to normal side). Incorrect because Rinne should be negative on the left in conductive loss.

 

Option C. Rinne negative in both ears, Weber does not lateralize: Suggests bilateral conductive loss (Rinne negative both sides, Weber midline). Incorrect as the audiogram clearly shows unilateral (left-sided) conductive loss.

 

Option D. Rinne positive in left ear, Rinne negative in right ear, Weber lateralized to left: Suggests right-sided conductive loss, not matching audiogram. Incorrect because Rinne should be negative in the left, not right.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In conductive hearing loss, Rinne test is negative on the affected side, and Weber test lateralizes to the same ear.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with sore throat and pain in the right ear that worsens while swallowing. On examination, he has enlarged, erythematous tonsils with exudates. Which cranial nerve is most likely responsible for the referred ear pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

This nerve innervates both the tonsillar region and the middle ear via the tympanic branch (Jacobson's nerve). Hence, inflammation in the tonsils (like in tonsillitis) can lead to referred pain in the ear. This is a classic case of referred otalgia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trigeminal nerve: Specifically, the auriculotemporal branch (V3) supplies the external ear and temporomandibular joint, and referred otalgia via this nerve usually comes from dental, TMJ, or oral cavity lesions, not the tonsils.

 

Option B. Facial nerve: Though it innervates muscles of facial expression, its role in referred otalgia is minimal. The nerve of Wrisberg (part of the facial nerve) may play a minor role but not in tonsillitis.

 

Option D. Auriculotemporal nerve: A branch of the mandibular nerve (V3). Involved in otalgia secondary to TMJ or dental pathologies, but not tonsillar inflammation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In tonsillitis, referred otalgia occurs via the glossopharyngeal nerve, which supplies both the tonsillar area and middle ear.

choices.text: High-resolution CT of the temporal bone

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with persistent foul-smelling discharge from the right ear and progressive hearing loss. On examination, attic retraction with keratin debris is noted. Cholesteatoma is suspected. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation to assess the extent of the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High-resolution CT of the temporal bone

 

HRCT is the investigation of choice for suspected cholesteatoma. It can identify bony erosions (ossicles, scutum, tegmen, lateral semicircular canal), extent of disease, and guide surgical planning.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Pure tone audiometry: Useful to assess the degree and type of hearing loss, but it does not provide anatomical details of the extent or complications of cholesteatoma.

 

Option B. Contrast-enhanced MRI brain: MRI is more useful for soft tissue delineation and assessing intracranial complications, but CT is superior for bony anatomy. MRI is reserved for recurrent/residual cholesteatoma post-surgery (using DWI sequences).

 

Option D. Tympanic membrane mobility testing (tympanometry): Can detect middle ear effusion or negative pressure, but not useful in diagnosing or staging cholesteatoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High-resolution CT temporal bone is the investigation of choice in suspected cholesteatoma, as it accurately defines bony erosion and disease extent.

questions.text: During quiet inspiration, which intrinsic laryngeal muscle is primarily responsible for opening the glottis by abducting the vocal cords?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior cricoarytenoid

 

This is the only muscle that abducts the vocal cords, pulling the arytenoid cartilages laterally to open the rima glottidis. It's essential for maintaining airway patency during breathing. Supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interarytenoid: Has two parts: transverse (unpaired) and oblique. Both work to adduct the arytenoid cartilages, thereby closing the glottis. They do not abduct.

 

Option B. Lateral cricoarytenoid: This muscle adducts the vocal cords by rotating the arytenoid cartilages medially, effectively narrowing the glottis.

 

Option D. Cricothyroid: This tenses the vocal cords to raise pitch (tensor), and is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, but has no role in abduction.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior cricoarytenoid is the only intrinsic muscle that abducts the vocal cords, crucial for glottic opening during respiration.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought with complaints of persistent unilateral nasal blockage and continuous watery nasal discharge since birth. There is no history of sneezing or allergy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Choanal atresia

 

This is a congenital failure of the bucconasal membrane to regress, leading to a blockage between the nasal cavity and nasopharynx. Most commonly unilateral, it presents with persistent watery or mucoid discharge from one nostril since birth and nasal obstruction. Seen in association with CHARGE syndrome. Diagnosed with failure to pass catheter, methylene blue test, nasal endoscopy, or CT.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital dacryocystocele: Presents as a swelling near the medial canthus of the eye, not nasal obstruction. It involves nasolacrimal duct, not the nasal cavity directly.

 

 

Option C. Infantile nasal polyp: Polyps are rare in infants, and usually bilateral when present. They are typically associated with allergic rhinitis or cystic fibrosis, and do not present since birth.

 

Option D. Foreign body nose: Presents with foul-smelling, purulent discharge and often has an acute onset. Not likely since birth and not watery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unilateral watery nasal discharge and obstruction since birth in an infant strongly suggests congenital choanal atresia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a history of bronchial asthma presents with nasal congestion, anosmia, and recurrent nasal polyps. He reports worsening of symptoms, including sneezing and breathlessness, after taking over-the-counter pain medications for a headache. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Samter’s triad

 

Also known as Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD), this classic triad includes:

 

  • Asthma
  • Nasal polyps
  • Aspirin or NSAID sensitivity

 

Patients may present with nasal congestion, recurrent nasal polyps, and worsening respiratory symptoms after NSAID use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS): Usually seen in immunocompetent patients with allergic mucin and fungal elements. Polyps may be present, but aspirin sensitivity is not a feature.

 

 

Option C. Vasomotor rhinitis: A non-allergic, non-infectious rhinitis caused by abnormal autonomic regulation. Presents with sneezing and rhinorrhea but not associated with asthma or NSAID sensitivity.

 

Option D. Rhinitis medicamentosa: Caused by overuse of topical nasal decongestants, leading to rebound congestion. There is no link to asthma or aspirin sensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Samter’s triad is defined by the presence of asthma, nasal polyps, and aspirin sensitivity, often presenting with exacerbation of symptoms after NSAID use.

choices.text: Observe the patient and monitor for spontaneous resolution
Cauterize the bleeding point with silver nitrate
Perform transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation
Proceed with external carotid artery ligation

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with severe recurrent epistaxis that does not resolve despite anterior and posterior nasal packing. What is the next best step in the management of this refractory nasal bleed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perform transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation

 

This is the next step in refractory epistaxis after packing fails. The sphenopalatine artery is the terminal branch of the internal maxillary artery and a major blood supply to the nasal mucosa. TESPAL is a safe and effective endoscopic procedure done at the sphenopalatine foramen, just posterior to the middle turbinate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observe the patient and monitor for spontaneous resolution: In a case where anterior and posterior nasal packs have failed, passive observation is not appropriate, as persistent bleeding can become life-threatening.

 

Option B. Cauterize the bleeding point with silver nitrate: Chemical cautery is used in anterior epistaxis where the bleeding point (often in Little’s area) is visible and localized. In this case, bleeding is severe and refractory, needing surgical control.

 

Option D. Proceed with external carotid artery ligation: This is reserved for cases where sphenopalatine and maxillary artery ligation have failed. It is a more invasive procedure with higher risks and is not the immediate next step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In refractory epistaxis not controlled by nasal packing, the next step is endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with progressive hearing loss and reports that she hears better in noisy environments. Otoscopy reveals an intact tympanic membrane with a faint reddish hue over the promontory. Audiometry shows a dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Otosclerosis

 

A primary lesion of the bony labyrinth, most often at the fissula ante fenestram, causing stapes footplate fixation. Classical features include:

 

  • Paracusis Willisii (hears better in noisy surroundings)
  • Schwartz sign: reddish hue seen through intact TM (seen in active lesions)
  • Carhart's notch: dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz on audiogram
  • Tuning fork: Rinne negative, Weber lateralizes to poorer ear (conductive loss)
  • Treatment: Stapedotomy > Stapedectomy

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presbycusis: Age-related bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, typically in older adults. Audiometry shows high-frequency sloping SNHL, not a 2000 Hz notch or conductive loss.

 

 

Option C. Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM): Usually associated with perforated TM, discharge, and does not present with Schwartz sign or Carhart’s notch.

 

 

Option D. Noise-induced hearing loss: Characterized by SNHL with a dip at 4000 Hz, not 2000 Hz. Occurs in individuals exposed to loud occupational or recreational noise.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A dip at 2000 Hz in bone conduction (Carhart's notch) with intact TM and Schwartz sign is diagnostic of otosclerosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic male recovering from COVID-19 presents with facial pain, nasal congestion, and a black necrotic patch on the hard palate. On examination, there is facial swelling and ptosis on the same side. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucormycosis

 

A rapidly invasive fungal infection caused by Mucor or Rhizopus, seen especially in post-COVID diabetic patients, particularly those treated with steroids. Key features include:

 

  • Facial pain, nasal discharge, and black eschar over the turbinates, palate, or septum
  • Invasion of orbit and brain
  • Diagnosis: Endoscopy with biopsy of middle turbinate, imaging (CT/MRI) shows black turbinate sign
  • Treatment: Surgical debridement + IV Amphotericin B

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal tuberculosis: Rare and usually presents as chronic nasal ulceration or granulations. It is not rapidly progressive and does not cause black eschars or tissue necrosis.

 

Option C. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: Typically presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and neck lymphadenopathy. It does not cause necrotic palatal eschar or rapid orbital spread.

 

 

Option D. Orbital cellulitis: Presents with painful eye movements, proptosis, and lid edema, usually secondary to sinusitis. It does not cause palatal necrosis or black eschar.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Black eschar on the palate or nasal cavity in an immunocompromised post-COVID diabetic patient is strongly indicative of mucormycosis, requiring urgent surgical and antifungal management.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with a low-grade fever, hoarseness of voice, inspiratory stridor, and a barking cough. On X-ray neck (AP view), there is a characteristic “steeple sign.” What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

 

Common in children 6 months to 3 years. Caused by Parainfluenza virus (most commonly). Presents with:

 

  • Barking (croupy) cough
  • Inspiratory stridor
  • Gradual onset
  • Steeple sign on AP neck X-ray: subglottic narrowing

Treated with steroids, humidification, and supportive care

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute epiglottitis: Caused by Haemophilus influenzae type B, presents with high-grade fever, toxic appearance, drooling, and tripod position. X-ray lateral view shows thumb sign, not steeple sign.

 

 

Option B. Foreign body in larynx: Typically presents with sudden onset stridor and choking, often during eating or playing. There is no fever or barky cough, and X-ray may show radiopaque shadow or air trapping, but not steeple sign.

 

Option D. Retropharyngeal abscess: Seen more in <5-year-old children, presents with high fever, drooling, neck stiffness, and bulging of posterior pharyngeal wall. Lateral neck X-ray shows widening of prevertebral space, not steeple sign.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Steeple sign on AP neck X-ray with barky cough and inspiratory stridor is diagnostic of croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis).

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with facial heaviness and nasal congestion. CT scan of the paranasal sinuses shows mucosal thickening in the sinus whose floor is related to the roots of premolars and molars. Which sinus is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maxillary sinus

 

It is the most commonly infected sinus, primarily due to:

 

  • Poor natural drainage (opening high on medial wall into middle meatus)
  • Proximity to upper molars and premolars (risk of oroantral fistula post-extraction)
  • It is also the earliest sinus to develop.
  • Triangular shape and gravity-dependent location contribute to stagnation of secretions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frontal sinus: Drains via the frontal infundibulum and recess, and is the last sinus to develop (absent at birth). Infections are less common compared to maxillary and ethmoid.

 

 

Option B. Sphenoid sinus: Least commonly involved in sinusitis. Located posteriorly and related to optic nerve and internal carotid artery. Infection can be dangerous due to proximity to these structures, but it is rarely the first sinus to be affected.

 

 

Option D. Posterior ethmoid sinus: More commonly involved in children, but overall less than maxillary in adults. They drain into the superior meatus, and pathologies may involve optic nerve or orbit in advanced cases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maxillary sinus is the most commonly infected paranasal sinus, owing to its poor drainage and proximity to upper teeth.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with gradual bilateral hearing loss, especially for high-frequency sounds. Which cochlear structure is primarily affected in this age-related hearing impairment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stria vascularis

 

Located in the scala media, the stria vascularis is responsible for secreting potassium-rich endolymph. In presbycusis (age-related sensorineural hearing loss), particularly the strial or metabolic type, there is degeneration of the stria vascularis, leading to reduced endolymph production, impaired hair cell function, and progressive bilateral SNHL, often affecting high frequencies first.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Modiolus: The central bony core of the cochlea, through which the cochlear nerve fibers travel. It does not degenerate in presbycusis.

 

Option C. Oval window: Site where the stapes footplate transmits vibrations into the inner ear (scala vestibuli). It is involved in conductive hearing, not typically affected in presbycusis.

 

Option D. Tectorial membrane: Lies above the organ of Corti, interacts with stereocilia on hair cells, but degeneration of this membrane is not the primary cause of presbycusis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In presbycusis, the stria vascularis degenerates, leading to age-related sensorineural hearing loss due to reduced endolymph production and metabolic support to the cochlea.

questions.text: A patient with frontal headache and suspected frontal sinusitis is referred for an X-ray. Which radiographic view is most appropriate to evaluate the frontal sinus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caldwell’s view

 

This is the investigation of choice for frontal sinus evaluation. Also shows anterior ethmoid air cells. In this view, the patient faces the X-ray plate with the forehead and nose touching it, and the central ray is angled caudally.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water’s view (Occipitomental): Best for maxillary sinus, not frontal. The head is tilted upward to project maxillary sinuses without superimposition from petrous ridges.

 

 

Option C. Submentovertical view (Basal view): Used primarily for sphenoid sinus and skull base fractures. It is not ideal for frontal sinus.

 

 

Option D. Towne’s view: Typically used to visualize the occipital bone and posterior fossa structures. It is not used for paranasal sinuses.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caldwell’s view (Occipitofrontal) is the preferred X-ray view for evaluating frontal sinus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient experiences sudden bouts of dry cough whenever the external auditory canal is cleaned with a cotton bud. This is due to stimulation of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arnold’s nerve

 

This is the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (CN X). It supplies the posterior and inferior wall of the external auditory canal. Stimulation of this nerve can trigger the ear-cough reflex, known as Arnold’s reflex, due to vagal sensory innervation extending to the bronchial tree.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jacobson’s nerve: This is the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX). It supplies the middle ear mucosa, not the external auditory canal. It’s involved in referred otalgia, not the cough reflex.

 

Option B. Auriculotemporal nerve: A branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), it supplies the anterior wall and roof of the external auditory canal and TMJ. It is not responsible for the cough reflex, but may be involved in referred pain from TMJ or dental causes.

 

Option D. Great auricular nerve: Arises from C2–C3 cervical plexus, and supplies the pinna and skin over the parotid region, not involved in the cough reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stimulation of Arnold’s nerve (auricular branch of the vagus nerve) in the external auditory canal can lead to a vagal-mediated cough reflex, known as Arnold’s reflex.

questions.text: A 30-year-old professional singer complains of recent onset hoarseness and inability to sing high-pitched notes after thyroid surgery. Laryngoscopic examination reveals a mildly bowed vocal cord on one side. Which of the following muscles is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricothyroid

 

This muscle is a tensor of the vocal cords and is essential for producing high-pitched sounds. It is the only intrinsic laryngeal muscle supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN). Injury to this nerve (commonly during thyroid surgery) results in hoarseness, bowing of the cord, and inability to reach high frequencies—classic in singers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior cricoarytenoid: The only abductor of the vocal cords. Its paralysis would lead to airway obstruction, not selective loss of high-pitched phonation.

 

Option C. Thyroarytenoid: Functions as a relaxer of the vocal cords, helps with fine tuning of pitch but not primarily responsible for high-pitched phonation. Supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN).

 

Option D. Interarytenoid: An adductor of the vocal cords, helps in closure during phonation. Its dysfunction leads to incomplete glottic closure, but not pitch modulation issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cricothyroid muscle tenses the vocal cords for high-pitched sound production and is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. Injury leads to loss of high-frequency voice, especially significant in singers.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient with a history of chronic frontal sinusitis now presents with gradually progressive, painless swelling of the upper eyelid and outward displacement of the eyeball. CT scan reveals erosion of the anterior frontal sinus wall and expansion of the sinus cavity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Frontal mucocele

 

A chronic complication of frontal sinusitis, where mucus gets trapped due to obstruction of drainage, leading to progressive expansion of the sinus cavity. This causes:

 

  • Nonaxial proptosis (due to orbital wall erosion)
  • Bony thinning or erosion of the sinus walls on CT
  • Painless swelling, typically over the forehead or orbit

 

Requires endoscopic or external surgical drainage

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frontal osteoma: A slow-growing benign bony tumor, often asymptomatic. It may cause sinus obstruction but does not typically cause proptosis or bony erosion unless secondarily infected.

 

 

Option C. Cavernous sinus thrombosis: Presents acutely with fever, ophthalmoplegia, and bilateral proptosis, not isolated frontal bone erosion or painless swelling.

 

 

Option D. Allergic fungal sinusitis (AFRS): Causes sinus expansion with heterogeneous densities and allergic mucin on imaging but typically involves multiple sinuses and presents with nasal polyps, not isolated frontal bony erosion and proptosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal mucocele is a complication of chronic sinusitis that leads to sinus expansion, bone erosion, and nonaxial proptosis.

questions.text: In a cochlear implant system, which component lies under the skin and functions to receive the signal from the external transmitter and send it to the electrode array?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Internal receiver-stimulator

 

This internal component is implanted under the skin (usually in the mastoid region). It receives the digital signals from the external transmitting coil and converts them into electrical impulses, which are then delivered to the electrode array inserted in the cochlea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Signal processor: This is an external component that processes the sound picked up by the microphone and converts it into digital signals before sending them to the transmitter coil.

 

Option C. Electrode array: This is the part of the implant that is inserted into the scala tympani of the cochlea. It delivers electrical signals directly to the auditory nerve fibers but does not receive or transmit external signals.

 

Option D. Microphone: An external component that captures ambient sound and passes it to the speech processor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal receiver-stimulator in a cochlear implant is responsible for receiving signals from the external coil and transmitting them to the electrode array inside the cochlea.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male from Southeast Asia presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, conductive hearing loss, and a painless neck mass. MRI shows a mass in the nasopharynx near the Eustachian tube. What is the most likely site of origin of this tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fossa of Rosenmüller

 

This pharyngeal recess is the most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC). It lies posterior to the Eustachian tube opening. Tumors here often obstruct the Eustachian tube, causing serous otitis media and conductive hearing loss. NPC is strongly associated with EBV infection, nitrosamine exposure, and has a bimodal age distribution (15–25 and 55–65 years).

 

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Posterior end of inferior turbinate: This is not a common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Tumors here would present more with nasal symptoms and less with otological or neurological features.

 

Option C. Torus tubarius: A ridge over the cartilaginous part of the Eustachian tube. Though adjacent, it is not the most common origin site for NPC.

 

Option D. Posterior nasal septum: Tumors originating here are usually midline nasal tumors and not typically associated with NPC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fossa of Rosenmüller is the most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, presenting with conductive hearing loss, nasal obstruction, and cervical lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with sudden high-grade fever, drooling of saliva, muffled speech, and prefers to sit leaning forward. There is inspiratory stridor and respiratory distress. Which of the following is the most characteristic clinical sign seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tripod posture

 

Children with acute epiglottitis often assume this position to maximize airway patency. They sit leaning forward with the neck extended and chin thrust out. It helps relieve the upper airway obstruction caused by a swollen epiglottis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barking cough: This is a hallmark of croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis), not epiglottitis.

 

Option B. Steeple sign: Seen on AP X-ray neck in croup, representing subglottic narrowing. Not seen in epiglottitis.

 

 

Option D. Bilateral tonsillar hypertrophy: Common in tonsillitis, not a specific feature of epiglottitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tripod posture is a classic sign in acute epiglottitis, helping the child maintain a patent airway in the presence of supraglottic obstruction.

choices.text: Irregular astigmatism due to suture-induced corneal distortion
Bacterial keratitis due to compromised ocular surface

questions.text: After undergoing a penetrating keratoplasty for advanced keratoconus. He reports persistent blurred vision, especially when trying to read or focus on distant objects, despite wearing corrective glasses. On slit-lamp examination, the corneal graft appears clear with intact sutures and no signs of inflammation, neovascularization, or epithelial defect. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his visual symptoms at this stage?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Irregular astigmatism due to suture-induced corneal distortion

questions.text: The total area of the retina seen in direct ophthalmoscopy is:
questions.solution: Ans. B) 2DD

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient presents with loss of vision in both eyes. On examination normal pupillary responses are seen with normal fundus. VER shows extinguished response. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Cortical blindness

questions.text: The test given below in the image is:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Stereopsis test

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a 15-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus presents for a routine ophthalmologic evaluation. He reports no acute visual complaints but admits to occasional episodes of blurred vision in the past. Fundus photography reveals multiple scattered, well-demarcated pale spots throughout the peripheral retina, sparing the macula. Visual acuity is 20/40 in both eyes. The photograph below was taken during his examination. Which of the following best explains the retinal findings seen in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Retina after Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP)

questions.solution: Ans. D) Hypermetropic refractive error found

questions.text: Wernicke’s hemianopic pupillary response is seen in lesions at:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Optic Tract

questions.text: A 35-year-old male on slit lamp shows keratic precipitates & aqueous flare in his right eye. No synechiae but a complicated cataract is seen. The probable diagnosis would be:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Heterochromic Iridocyclitis Fuch’s

questions.text: A 14-year-old obese girl presents with a headache. She states that the headache has been on and off for weeks and has a moderate intensity. She also states that she has had intermittent loss of vision for seconds at a time for the last two to three days. Physical examination reveals the above image. A noncontrast head CT scan is normal. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Lumbar Puncture with opening pressure

questions.text: Aqueous as compared to plasma has all more, except:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Higher glucose

questions.text: A 66-year-old male patient with a history of gradually progressive painless diminution of vision since last 3 years presents with a 2 day history of ciliary congestion, photo­phobia, increased blurring of vision and on exami­nation has a deep anterior chamber in the right eye. The left eye is normal. The diagnosis and its management is:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Phacolytic glaucoma and cataract surgery

questions.text: Identify the condition.
questions.solution: Ans. C) Angular conjunctivitis

questions.text: A value of 0.75D was deduced from the retinoscopy reading as a part of drug correction. The likely drug used was:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Cyclopentolate

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents with a history of progressive vision loss and night blindness. Upon examination, the patient displays characteristic retinal degeneration with peripheral bone spicule pigmentation. Which of the following syndromes is not likely associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Marfan syndrome.

Povidone iodine eye drops 2 days prior to surgery
Intraoperative use of povidone iodine in Irrigating BSS

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important factor in the prevention of endophthalmitis in cataract surgery?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Preoperative part preparation with povidone iodine

questions.text: Argon laser trabeculoplasty is used in:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Primary open glaucoma

choices.text: Mostly results from a penetrating wound
Dalen Fuch's nodules may be seen

questions.text: All of the following are true for sympathetic ophthalmitis except:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Affects the injured eye

choices.text: Retinal pigment epithelial dispersion due to blunt trauma
Dislocation of the lens causing zonular rupture
Impression of the pupillary pigment on the anterior lens capsule

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the emergency department after being struck in the left eye with a cricket ball. He reports pain, blurred vision, and photophobia in the affected eye. On examination, visual acuity is reduced in the left eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals a circular ring of brownish pigment on the anterior surface of the lens, corresponding in shape to the pupillary margin. The anterior chamber is quiet, and intraocular pressure is within normal limits. Fundus examination is unremarkable. Which of the following best explains the finding seen on slit-lamp examination?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Impression of the pupillary pigment on the anterior lens capsule

Proper refractive correction, amblyopia therapy followed by surgical correction
Prescribe glasses and defer surgery until the child is 5 yrs old

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with the following presentation of 6 months duration. What is appropriate management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Proper refractive correction, amblyopia therapy followed by surgical correction

Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Brimonidine eye drops can cause drowsiness and lethargy in elderly patients.

 

Reason (R): Brimonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that can undergo systemic absorption and exert central nervous system depressant effects.
questions.solution: Ans. A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman from Jaipur presents with multiple episodes of syncope over the last 3 months, often occurring at rest or during sleep. She denies chest pain or palpitations. Her father died suddenly in his early 40s. Physical examination and laboratory tests, including troponins and electrolytes, are unremarkable. Echocardiography shows a structurally normal heart. Her ECG is shown below. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator

questions.text: A 45-year-old male shipyard worker presents with gradually worsening shortness of breath over the past 6 months. He denies chest pain or cough and has never smoked. He worked in ship insulation for 20 years. On examination, bibasal fine crackles are heard. CXR is shown below. PR shows FEV1: 65%, FVC: 60%, FEV1/FVC: 84%, DLCO: 48%. These lesions the CXR are precursors of which of the following cancer?
questions.solution: Ans. D) None

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman from Delhi with long-standing poorly controlled  type 2 diabetes presents with swelling of the face, proximal muscle weakness, and easy bruishing. Examination reveals central obesity, purple striae, and facial plethora, BP is 164/100 mmHg. Her serum cortisol is elevated. Pituitary MRI is normal, and a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows <50% suppression of ACTH levels. What is the next best step?
questions.solution: Ans. A) FDG-PET scan

questions.text: A 28-year-old man from Bengaluru presents with progressive stiffness in both legs for the past 10 years, which has gradually worsened his walking. He denies any sensory loss, coordination issues, or bladder symptoms. His older brother has a similar walking difficulty. On examination, there is bilateral lower limb spasticity, hyperreflexia, and extensor plantar responses, with cerebellar or sensory deficits. MRI of the brain and spine is reported normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Hereditary spastic paraplegia

questions.text: A 66-year-old man from Ahmedabad presents with progressive fatigue and unintended weight loss over the past 3 months. Examination reveals massive splenomegaly. Hb 8.5 g/dL, WBC 3,200/mm³, platelets 65,000/mm³. Peripheral smear is shown. Bone marrow: 3+ fibrosis. JAK2 V617F mutation positive. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Ruxolitinib

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman from Hyderabad presents with facial puffiness, cola-colored urine, and elevated blood pressure. Lab Investigations show: Labs shown RBC casts in urine, proteinuria (2.8 g/day), serum creatinine 3.7 mg/dL, positive ANA (1:640, homogenous) and anti-dsDNA antibodies. Renal biopsy is shown. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Cyclophosphamide + high dose prednisolone

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with complaints of pain and stiffness in the fingers, along with chronic heel pain and morning stiffness. On physical examination, he has the following finding but no visible skin lesions. An X-ray of the hand shows is shown. Laboratory investigations reveal that he is HLA-B27 positive and rheumatoid factor (RF) negative. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Psoriatic arthritis

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with cirrhosis presents with confusion and altered sleep-wake cycle. He is disoriented with the following finding. Doppler ultrasound reveals hepatofugal flow in the portal vein. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Lactulose + rifaximin

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman from rural Bihar presents with 3 weeks of low-grade fever, unintentional weight loss, and progressive weakness. On examination, she has massive splenomegaly and pallor. Lab tests reveal pancytopenia. And the rK39 rapid diagnostic test is positive. What is the treatment of choice for this patient’s conditions?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Liposomal amphotericin B

questions.text: A 66-year-old man with ischemic cardiomyopathy and left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 28% presents with persistent NYHA Class III symptoms  despite being on optimal guideline- directed medical therapy, including a carvedilol ramipril, spironolactone, and dapagliflozin. His ECG shown below. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: Ans. B) CRT-D

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with left lower limb pain and swelling. Doppler confirms DVT. Coagulation profile shows a prolonged aPTT and mixing study fails to correct aPTT. She is currently not on any drugs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Antiphospholipid syndrome

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with HIV infection (CD4 = 75 cells/mm3) and miliary tuberculosis was started on antitubercular therapy (ATT) and antiretroviral therapy (ART). Three weeks later, he presents with fever, worsening cough, and new cervical lymphadenopathy. Repeat CB-NAAT from sputum is negative. What is the most likely cause of his clinical worsening?
questions.solution: Ans. D) TB-IRIS

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with kidney stones constipation, and fatigue. Labs: calcium 12.5 mg/dl, PTH elevated, prolactin normal. He has a skin lesion that is shown below. He had surgery for pheochromocytoma last year. What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) MEN type 2A

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance. On examination, he has pale conjunctivae. Labs = 7.8g/dL, MCV 68fL, S. Ferritin 8ng/mL, UGI scopy shows multiple angioectasias in proximal duodenum. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Endoscopic argon plasma coagulation

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent pneumonia since childhood, digital clubbing, and infertility. He also reports persistent nasal congestion and chronic cough. On examination, there are bilateral coarse crepitations. Chest CT reveals central bronchiectasis and mucous plugging. What is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Primary ciliary dyskinesia

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive headache and vomiting for the past 2 weeks. He has no fever, seizures or focal neurological deficits. MRI of the brain is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Meningioma

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with fatigue, arthritis photosensitivity, and oral ulcers. Urine shows proteinuria and RBC casts. C3/C4 is low. What antibody is most specific for her diseases?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Anti-Smith

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with chronic tophaceous gout and stage 4 chronic kidney disease (CKD) presents with severe joint pain and visible tophi. His serum uric acid is 10.5 mg/dL. He previously developed a rash with allopurinol and had gastrointestinal side effects with febuxostat. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Begin pegloticase infusion

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with sepsis from pneumonia is intubated in the ICU. His ABG shows: pH 7.11, PaCO2 58 mmHg, HCO3 - 19 mEq/L. What is the primary acid-base disorder?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis

questions.text: A 55-year-old ICU patient has been receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) for the past 10 days. He now develops confusion and seizures. Labs: Mg2+ 0.7 mg/dL. Ca2 6.5 mg/dL, K+ 2.9 mEq/L & PO4 1 mg/dL. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Refeeding syndrome

choices.text: Urgent pericardiocentesis with CT imaging follow-up
Immediate surgical consult for suspected aortic dissection
Start IV norepinephrine and defer intervention
Administer IV thrombolytics for possible pulmonary embolism

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled hypertension and smoking presents with acute dyspnea, chest pain and hypotension. BP is 80/60 mmHg, heart rate is 110 bpm and has jugular venous distention. ECG and CXR are show below. What is the next best step?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Immediate surgical consult for suspected aortic dissection

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with episodes of confusion, palpitations, and sweating which consistently resolve after meals. During a supervised 72-hour fast, she develops hypoglycemia (glucose 42 mg/dL) accompanied by elevated insulin and C-peptide levels. What is the next best investigation?
questions.solution: Ans. C) CT abdomen with contrast

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with persistent fever, weight loss, and a new diastolic murmur. Transthoracic echocardiography image is show below. Blood cultures taken over 72 hours are negative despite appropriate incubation. What is the best next step?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Order Brucella and Coxiella serology

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with fever, headache, vomiting, and neck stiffness for 10 days. MRI brain is shows below. CSF is lymphocytic with low glucose and high protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Tuberculous meningitis

questions.text: A 64-year-old retired teacher from Amritsar presents with progressively worsening fatigue, loss of appetite, and dull lower back pain for 3 months. His family reports recent episodes of confusion. On evaluation, his creatinine is 3.1 mg/dL, hemoglobin 8.9 g/gL, and serum calcium 11.6 mg/dL. Urine dipstick is negative for protein, but serum total protein is elevated. What is the most likely renal pathology?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Myeloma cast nephropathy

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of acromegaly underwent transsphenoidal resection 9 months ago. He continues to have symptoms such as coarse facial features and hand enlargement. Laboratory tests show persistently elevated IGF-1 and GH levels. MRI sella reveals a small residual pituitary tumor. He is already on monthly octreotide LAR 30 mg. What is the best next step?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Add pegvisomant

choices.text: Perform extended red cell antigen matching

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with chronic anemia (Hb 7.2 g/dL) due to myelodysplastic syndrome receives a packed RBC transfusion. Ten days later, he presents with jaundice, dark urine, and Hb drop to 5.8 g/dL. Coombs test is positive. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Perform extended red cell antigen matching

questions.text: A 65-year-old man from Hyderabad with a known history of severe COPD is intubated in the ICU due to type 2 respiratory failure. He is being ventilated on volume assist-control mode. A few hours later, the nurse notes he has become agitated and tachypneic with visible accessory muscle use. Ventilator image is shown below what is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Add sedation + neuromuscular blockade

questions.text: A 36-year-old man from Nagpur with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with severe epigastric pain and multiple episodes  of vomiting for 2 days. Serum amylase is 980 U/L. He  is started on IV fluids and kept NPO. On  day 3 , his BP 98/60 mmHg, HR 112/min, has a creatinine of 1.9 mg/dL, and O2 saturation of 88% on room air. A contrast-enhanced CT scan shows peripancreatic fat stranding and fluid collections. What is the most accurate diagnosis regarding his condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Severe acute pancreatitis

questions.text: A 64-year-old from Lucknow with known stage 3 chronic kidney disease presents with a sudden increase in serum creatinine from 1.9 mg/dL to 4.8 mg/dL over 5 days. He was recently started on lisinopril, furosemide, and indomethacin for hypertension and knee arthritis. His BP is 100/70 mmHg. And urinalysis reveals bland urine sediment. What is the likely mechanism?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Hemodynamic renal injury
